summary: Winston Scott was the Chief of Station for the CIA in Mexico. A memorandum details a conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Mr. Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico, where Lopez Mateos conveyed his friendship to the United States, his invitation to President Dorticos of Cuba, and his decision not to invite Fidel Castro to Mexico. His name appears in a list of individuals connected with the CIA station in Mexico City during Lee Harvey Oswald's visit. This list was compiled from David Phillips' testimony and Boris Tarasoff's interviews. Robert T. Shaw's testimony before the HSCA also mentions CIA activities in Mexico City in 1963 related to Lee Harvey Oswald and Cuban operations.
significance: Winston Scott's significance in the JFK context lies in his role as the CIA Chief of Station in Mexico City during Lee Harvey Oswald's visit. His position made him a key figure in any CIA activities related to Oswald or Cuban operations in Mexico. Mentions of his name in connection with David Phillips' testimony and Boris Tarasoff's interviews, as well as Robert T. Shaw's testimony before the HSCA, suggest his potential involvement in or knowledge of events surrounding Oswald's activities in Mexico City prior to the assassination.
